verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 1:1
verses.text: Confessions Book X: Chapter I.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 1:2
verses.text: —In God Alone is the Hope and Joy of Man.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 1:3
verses.text: Let me know Thee, O Thou who knowest me; let me know Thee, as I am known.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 1:4
verses.text: O Thou strength of my soul, enter into it, and prepare it for Thyself, that Thou mayest have and hold it without "spot or wrinkle".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 1:5
verses.text: This is my hope, "therefore have I spoken;" and in this hope do I rejoice, when I rejoice soberly.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 1:6
verses.text: Other things of this life ought the less to be sorrowed for, the more they are sorrowed for; and ought the more to be sorrowed for, the less men do sorrow for them.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 1:7
verses.text: For behold, "Thou desirest truth," seeing that he who does it "cometh to the light".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 1:8
verses.text: This wish I to do in confession in my heart before Thee, and in my writing before many witnesses.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:2
verses.text: —That All Things are Manifest to God.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:3
verses.text: That Confession Unto Him is Not Made by the Words of the Flesh, But of the Soul, and the Cry of Reflection.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:4
verses.text: And from Thee, O Lord, unto whose eyes the depths of man's conscience are naked, what in me could be hidden though I were unwilling to confess to Thee? For so should I hide Thee from myself, not myself from Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:5
verses.text: But now, because my groaning witnesseth that I am dissatisfied with myself, Thou shinest forth, and satisfiest, and art beloved and desired; that I may blush for myself, and renounce myself, and choose Thee, and may neither please Thee nor myself, except in Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:6
verses.text: To Thee, then, O Lord, am I manifest, whatever I am, and with what fruit I may confess unto Thee I have spoken.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:7
verses.text: Nor do I it with words and sounds of the flesh, but with the words of the soul, and that cry of reflection which Thine ear knoweth.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:8
verses.text: For when I am wicked, to confess to Thee is naught but to be dissatisfied with myself; but when I am truly devout, it is naught but not to attribute it to myself, because Thou, O Lord, dost "bless the righteous;" but first Thou justifiest him "ungodly".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:9
verses.text: My confession, therefore, O my God, in Thy sight, is made unto Thee silently, and yet not silently.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:10
verses.text: For in noise it is silent, in affection it cries aloud.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 2:11
verses.text: For neither do I give utterance to anything that is right unto men which Thou hast not heard from me before, nor dost Thou hear anything of the kind from me which Thyself saidst not first unto me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 3:2
verses.text: —He Who Confesseth Rightly Unto God Best Knoweth Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 3:3
verses.text: What then have I to do with men, that they should hear my confessions, as if they were going to cure all my diseases? A people curious to know the lives of others, but slow to correct their own.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 3:4
verses.text: Why do they desire to hear from me what I am, who are unwilling to hear from Thee what they are? And how can they tell, when they hear from me of myself, whether I speak the truth, seeing that no man knoweth what is in man, "save the spirit of man which is in him "? But if they hear from Thee aught concerning themselves, they will not be able to say, "The Lord lieth".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 3:5
verses.text: For what is it to hear from Thee of themselves, but to know themselves? And who is he that knoweth himself and saith, "It is false," unless he himself lieth? But because "charity believeth all things" (amongst those at all events whom by union with itself it maketh one), I too, O Lord, also so confess unto Thee that men may hear, to whom I cannot prove whether I confess the truth, yet do they believe me whose ears charity openeth unto me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 3:6
verses.text: But yet do Thou, my most secret Physician, make clear to me what fruit I may reap by doing it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 3:7
verses.text: For the confessions of my past sins,—which Thou hast "forgiven" and "covered," that Thou mightest make me happy in Thee, changing my soul by faith and Thy sacrament,—when they are read and heard, stir up the heart, that it sleep not in despair and say, "I cannot;" but that it may awake in the love of Thy mercy and the sweetness of Thy grace, by which he that is weak is strong, if by it he is made conscious of his own weakness.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 3:8
verses.text: As for the good, they take delight in hearing of the past errors of such as are now freed from them; and they delight, not because they are errors, but because they have been and are so no longer.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 3:9
verses.text: For what fruit, then, O Lord my God, to whom my conscience maketh her daily confession, more confident in the hope of Thy mercy than in her own innocency,—for what fruit, I beseech Thee, do I confess even to men in Thy presence by this book what I am at this time, not what I have been? For that fruit I have both seen and spoken of, but what I am at this time, at the very moment of making my confessions, divers people desire to know, both who knew me and who knew me not,—who have heard of or from me,—but their ear is not at my heart, where I am whatsoever I am.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 3:10
verses.text: They are desirous, then, of hearing me confess what I am within, where they can neither stretch eye, nor ear, nor mind; they desire it as those willing to believe,—but will they understand? For charity, by which they are good, says unto them that I do not lie in my confessions, and she in them believes me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:2
verses.text: —That in His Confessions He May Do Good, He Considers Others.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:3
verses.text: But for what fruit do they desire this? Do they wish me happiness when they learn how near, by Thy gift, I come unto Thee; and to pray for me, when they learn how much I am kept back by my own weight? To such will I declare myself.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:4
verses.text: For it is no small fruit, O Lord my God, that by many thanks should be given to Thee on our behalf, and that by many Thou shouldest be entreated for us.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:5
verses.text: Let the fraternal soul love that in me which Thou teachest should be loved, and lament that in me which Thou teachest should be lamented.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:6
verses.text: Let a fraternal and not an alien soul do this, nor that "of strange children, whose mouth speaketh vanity, and their right hand is a right hand of falsehood," but that fraternal one which, when it approves me, rejoices for me, but when it disapproves me, is sorry for me; because whether it approves or disapproves it loves me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:7
verses.text: To such will I declare myself; let them breathe freely at my good deeds, and sigh over my evil ones.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:8
verses.text: My good deeds are Thy institutions and Thy gifts, my evil ones are my delinquencies and Thy judgments.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:9
verses.text: Let them breathe freely at the one, and sigh over the other; and let hymns and tears ascend into Thy sight out of the fraternal hearts—Thy censers.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:10
verses.text: And do Thou, O Lord, who takest delight in the incense of Thy holy temple, have mercy upon me according to Thy great mercy, "for Thy name's sake;" and on no account leaving what Thou hast begun in me, do Thou complete what is imperfect in me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:11
verses.text: This is the fruit of my confessions, not of what I was, but of what I am, that I may confess this not before Thee only, in a secret exultation with trembling, and a secret sorrow with hope, but in the ears also of the believing sons of men,—partakers of my joy, and sharers of my mortality, my fellow-citizens and the companions of my pilgrimage, those who are gone before, and those that are to follow after, and the comrades of my way.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:12
verses.text: These are Thy servants, my brethren, those whom Thou wishest to be Thy sons; my masters, whom Thou hast commanded me to serve, if I desire to live with and of Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:13
verses.text: But this Thy word were little to me did it command in speaking, without going before in acting.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:14
verses.text: This then do I both in deed and word, this I do under Thy wings, in too great danger, were it not that my soul, under Thy wings, is subject unto Thee, and my weakness known unto Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:15
verses.text: I am a little one, but my Father liveth for ever, and my Defender is "sufficient" for me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:16
verses.text: For He is the same who begat me and who defends me; and Thou Thyself art all my good; even Thou, the Omnipotent, who art with me, and that before I am with Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:17
verses.text: To such, therefore, whom Thou commandest me to serve will I declare, not what I was, but what I now am, and what I still am.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:18
verses.text: But neither do I judge myself.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 4:19
verses.text: Thus then I would be heard.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 5:2
verses.text: —That Man Knoweth Not Himself Wholly.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 5:3
verses.text: For it is Thou, Lord, that judgest me; for although no "man knoweth the things of a man, save the spirit of man which is in him," yet is there something of man which "the spirit of man which is in him" itself knoweth not.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 5:4
verses.text: But Thou, Lord, who hast made him, knowest him wholly.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 5:5
verses.text: I indeed, though in Thy sight I despise myself, and reckon "myself but dust and ashes," yet know something concerning Thee, which I know not concerning myself.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 5:6
verses.text: And assuredly "now we see through a glass darkly," not yet "face to face".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 5:7
verses.text: So long, therefore, as I be "absent" from Thee, I am more "present" with myself than with Thee; and yet know I that Thou canst not suffer violence; but for myself I know not what temptations I am able to resist, and what I am not able.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 5:8
verses.text: But there is hope, because Thou art faithful, who wilt not suffer us to be tempted above that we are able, but wilt with the temptation also make a way to escape, that we may be able to bear it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 5:9
verses.text: I would therefore confess what I know concerning myself; I will confess also what I know not concerning myself.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 5:10
verses.text: And because what I do know of myself, I know by Thee enlightening me; and what I know not of myself, so long I know not until the time when my "darkness be as the noonday" in Thy sight.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:2
verses.text: —The Love of God, in His Nature Superior to All Creatures, is Acquired by the Knowledge of the Senses and the Exercise of Reason.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:3
verses.text: Not with uncertain, but with assured consciousness do I love Thee, O Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:4
verses.text: Thou hast stricken my heart with Thy word, and I loved Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:5
verses.text: And also the heaven, and earth, and all that is therein, behold, on every side they say that I should love Thee; nor do they cease to speak unto all, "so that they are without excuse".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:6
verses.text: But more profoundly wilt Thou have mercy on whom Thou wilt have mercy, and compassion on whom Thou wilt have compassion, otherwise do both heaven and earth tell forth Thy praises to deaf ears.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:7
verses.text: But what is it that I love in loving Thee? Not corporeal beauty, nor the splendour of time, nor the radiance of the light, so pleasant to our eyes, nor the sweet melodies of songs of all kinds, nor the fragrant smell of flowers, and ointments, and spices, not manna and honey, not limbs pleasant to the embracements of flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:8
verses.text: I love not these things when I love my God; and yet I love a certain kind of light, and sound, and fragrance, and food, and embracement in loving my God, who is the light, sound, fragrance, food, and embracement of my inner man—where that light shineth unto my soul which no place can contain, where that soundeth which time snatcheth not away, where there is a fragrance which no breeze disperseth, where there is a food which no eating can diminish, and where that clingeth which no satiety can sunder.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:9
verses.text: This is what I love, when I love my God.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:10
verses.text: And what is this? I asked the earth; and it answered, "I am not He;" and whatsoever are therein made the same confession.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:11
verses.text: I asked the sea and the deeps, and the creeping things that lived, and they replied, "We are not thy God, seek higher than we".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:12
verses.text: I asked the breezy air, and the universal air with its inhabitants answered, "Anaximenes was deceived, I am not God".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:13
verses.text: I asked the heavens, the sun, moon, and stars: "Neither," say they, "are we the God whom thou seekest".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:14
verses.text: And I answered unto all these things which stand about the door of my flesh, "Ye have told me concerning my God, that ye are not He; tell me something about Him".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:15
verses.text: And with a loud voice they exclaimed, "He made us".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:16
verses.text: My questioning was my observing of them; and their beauty was their reply.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:17
verses.text: And I directed my thoughts to myself, and said, "Who art thou?" And I answered, "A man".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:18
verses.text: And lo, in me there appear both body and soul, the one without, the other within.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:19
verses.text: By which of these should I seek my God, whom I had sought through the body from earth to heaven, as far as I was able to send messengers—the beams of mine eyes? But the better part is that which is inner; for to it, as both president and judge, did all these my corporeal messengers render the answers of heaven and earth and all things therein, who said, "We are not God, but He made us".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:20
verses.text: These things was my inner man cognizant of by the ministry of the outer; I, the inner man, knew all this—I, the soul, through the senses of my body.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:21
verses.text: I asked the vast bulk of the earth of my God, and it answered me, "I am not He, but He made me".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:22
verses.text: Is not this beauty visible to all whose senses are unimpaired? Why then doth it not speak the same things unto all? Animals, the very small and the great, see it, but they are unable to question it, because their senses are not endowed with reason to enable them to judge on what they report.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:23
verses.text: But men can question it, so that "the invisible things of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:24
verses.text: are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made;" but by loving them, they are brought into subjection to them; and subjects are not able to judge.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:25
verses.text: Neither do the creatures reply to such as question them, unless they can judge; nor will they alter their voice (that is, their beauty), if so be one man only sees, another both sees and questions, so as to appear one way to this man, and another to that; but appearing the same way to both, it is mute to this, it speaks to that—yea, verily, it speaks unto all but they only understand it who compare that voice received from without with the truth within.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:26
verses.text: For the truth declareth unto me, "Neither heaven, nor earth, nor any body is thy God".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:27
verses.text: This, their nature declareth unto him that beholdeth them.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:28
verses.text: "They are a mass; a mass is less in part than in the whole".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 6:29
verses.text: Now, O my soul, thou art my better part, unto thee I speak; for thou animatest the mass of thy body, giving it life, which no body furnishes to a body but thy God is even unto thee the Life of life.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 7:2
verses.text: —That God is to Be Found Neither from the Powers of the Body Nor of the Soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 7:3
verses.text: What then is it that I love when I love my God? Who is He that is above the head of my soul? By my soul itself will I mount up unto Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 7:4
verses.text: I will soar beyond that power of mine whereby I cling to the body, and fill the whole structure of it with life.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 7:5
verses.text: Not by that power do I find my God; for then the horse and the mule, "which have no understanding," might find Him, since it is the same power by which their bodies also live.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 7:6
verses.text: But there is another power, not that only by which I quicken, but that also by which I endow with sense my flesh, which the Lord hath made for me; bidding the eye not to hear, and the ear not to see; but that, for me to see by, and this, for me to hear by; and to each of the other senses its own proper seat and office, which being different, I, the single mind, do through them govern.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 7:7
verses.text: I will soar also beyond this power of mine; for this the horse and mule possess, for they too discern through the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:2
verses.text: ——Of the Nature and the Amazing Power of Memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:3
verses.text: I will soar, then, beyond this power of my nature also, ascending by degrees unto Him who made me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:4
verses.text: And I enter the fields and roomy chambers of memory, where are the treasures of countless images, imported into it from all manner of things by the senses.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:5
verses.text: There is treasured up whatsoever likewise we think, either by enlarging or diminishing, or by varying in any way whatever those things which the sense hath arrived at; yea, and whatever else hath been entrusted to it and stored up, which oblivion hath not yet engulfed and buried.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:6
verses.text: When I am in this storehouse, I demand that what I wish should be brought forth, and some things immediately appear; others require to be longer sought after, and are dragged, as it were, out of some hidden receptacle; others, again, hurry forth in crowds, and while another thing is sought and inquired for, they leap into view, as if to say, "Is it not we, perchance?" These I drive away with the hand of my heart from before the face of my remembrance, until what I wish be discovered making its appearance out of its secret cell.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:7
verses.text: Other things suggest themselves without effort, and in continuous order, just as they are called for,—those in front giving place to those that follow, and in giving place are treasured up again to be forthcoming when I wish it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:8
verses.text: All of which takes place when I repeat a thing from memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:9
verses.text: All these things, each of which entered by its own avenue, are distinctly and under general heads there laid up: as, for example, light, and all colours and forms of bodies, by the eyes; sounds of all kinds by the ears; all smells by the passage of the nostrils; all flavours by that of the mouth; and by the sensation of the whole body is brought in what is hard or soft, hot or cold, smooth or rough, heavy or light, whether external or internal to the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:10
verses.text: All these doth that great receptacle of memory, with its many and indescribable departments, receive, to be recalled and brought forth when required; each, entering by its own door, is hid up in it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:11
verses.text: And yet the things themselves do not enter it, but only the images of the things perceived are there ready at hand for thought to recall.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:12
verses.text: And who can tell how these images are formed, notwithstanding that it is evident by which of the senses each has been fetched in and treasured up? For even while I live in darkness and silence, I can bring out colours in memory if I wish, and discern between black and white, and what others I wish; nor yet do sounds break in and disturb what is drawn in by mine eyes, and which I am considering, seeing that they also are there, and are concealed, laid up, as it were, apart.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:13
verses.text: For these too I can summon if I please, and immediately they appear.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:14
verses.text: And though my tongue be at rest, and my throat silent, yet can I sing as much as I will; and those images of colours, which notwithstanding are there, do not interpose themselves and interrupt when another treasure is under consideration which flowed in through the ears.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:15
verses.text: So the remaining things carried in and heaped up by the other senses, I recall at my pleasure.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:16
verses.text: And I discern the scent of lilies from that of violets while smelling nothing; and I prefer honey to grape-syrup, a smooth thing to a rough, though then I neither taste nor handle, but only remember.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:17
verses.text: These things do I within, in that vast chamber of my memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:18
verses.text: For there are nigh me heaven, earth, sea, and whatever I can think upon in them, besides those which I have forgotten.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:19
verses.text: There also do I meet with myself, and recall myself,—what, when, or where I did a thing, and how I was affected when I did it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:20
verses.text: There are all which I remember, either by personal experience or on the faith of others.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:21
verses.text: Out of the same supply do I myself with the past construct now this, now that likeness of things, which either I have experienced, or, from having experienced, have believed; and thence again future actions, events, and hopes, and upon all these again do I meditate as if they were present.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:22
verses.text: "I will do this or that," say I to myself in that vast womb of my mind, filled with the images of things so many and so great, "and this or that shall follow upon it".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:23
verses.text: "Oh that this or that might come to pass!" "God avert this or that!" Thus speak I to myself; and when I speak, the images of all I speak about are present, out of the same treasury of memory; nor could I say anything at all about them were the images absent.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:24
verses.text: Great is this power of memory, exceeding great, O my God,—an inner chamber large and boundless! Who has plumbed the depths thereof? Yet it is a power of mine, and appertains unto my nature; nor do I myself grasp all that I am.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:25
verses.text: Therefore is the mind too narrow to contain itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:26
verses.text: And where should that be which it doth not contain of itself? Is it outside and not in itself? How is it, then, that it doth not grasp itself? A great admiration rises upon me; astonishment seizes me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:27
verses.text: And men go forth to wonder at the heights of mountains, the huge waves of the sea, the broad flow of the rivers, the extent of the ocean, and the courses of the stars, and omit to wonder at themselves; nor do they marvel that when I spoke of all these things, I was not looking on them with my eyes, and yet could not speak of them unless those mountains, and waves, and rivers, and stars which I saw, and that ocean which I believe in, I saw inwardly in my memory, and with the same vast spaces between as when I saw them abroad.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:28
verses.text: But I did not by seeing appropriate them when I looked on them with my eyes; nor are the things themselves with me, but their images.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 8:29
verses.text: And I knew by what corporeal sense each made impression on me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 9:2
verses.text: —Not Only Things, But Also Literature and Images, are Taken from the Memory, and are Brought Forth by the Act of Remembering.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 9:3
verses.text: And yet are not these all that the illimitable capacity of my memory retains.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 9:4
verses.text: Here also is all that is apprehended of the liberal sciences, and not yet forgotten—removed as it were into an inner place, which is not a place; nor are they the images which are retained, but the things themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 9:5
verses.text: For what is literature, what skill in disputation, whatsoever I know of all the many kinds of questions there are, is so in my memory, as that I have not taken in the image and left the thing without, or that it should have sounded and passed away like a voice imprinted on the ear by that trace, whereby it might be recorded, as though it sounded when it no longer did so; or as an odour while it passes away, and vanishes into wind, affects the sense of smell, whence it conveys the image of itself into the memory, which we realize in recollecting; or like food, which assuredly in the belly hath now no taste, and yet hath a kind of taste in the memory, or like anything that is by touching felt by the body, and which even when removed from us is imagined by the memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 9:6
verses.text: For these things themselves are not put into it, but the images of them only are caught up, with a marvellous quickness, and laid up, as it were, in most wonderful garners, and wonderfully brought forth when we remember.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:2
verses.text: —Literature is Not Introduced to the Memory Through the Senses, But is Brought Forth from Its More Secret Places.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:3
verses.text: But truly when I hear that there are three kinds of questions, "Whether a thing is?—what it is?—of what kind it is?" I do indeed hold fast the images of the sounds of which these words are composed, and I know that those sounds passed through the air with a noise, and now are not.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:4
verses.text: But the things themselves which are signified by these sounds I never arrived at by any sense of the body, nor ever perceived them otherwise than by my mind; and in my memory have I laid up not their images, but themselves, which, how they entered into me, let them tell if they are able.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:5
verses.text: For I examine all the gates of my flesh, but find not by which of them they entered.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:6
verses.text: For the eyes say, "If they were coloured, we announced them".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:7
verses.text: The ears say, "If they sounded, we gave notice of them".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:8
verses.text: The nostrils say, "If they smell, they passed in by us".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:9
verses.text: The sense of taste says, "If they have no flavour, ask not me".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:10
verses.text: The touch says, "If it have not body, I handled it not, and if I never handled it, I gave no notice of it".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:11
verses.text: Whence and how did these things enter into my memory? I know not how.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:12
verses.text: For when I learned them, I gave not credit to the heart of another man, but perceived them in my own; and I approved them as true, and committed them to it, laying them up, as it were, whence I might fetch them when I willed.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:13
verses.text: There, then, they were, even before I learned them, but were not in my memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 10:14
verses.text: Where were they, then, or wherefore, when they were spoken, did I acknowledge them, and say, "So it is, it is true," unless as being already in the memory, though so put back and concealed, as it were, in more secret caverns, that had they not been drawn forth by the advice of another I would not, perchance, have been able to conceive of them?.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 11:2
verses.text: —What It is to Learn and to Think.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 11:3
verses.text: Wherefore we find that to learn these things, whose images we drink not in by our senses, but perceive within as they are by themselves, without images, is nothing else but by meditation as it were to concentrate, and by observing to take care that those notions which the memory did before contain scattered and confused, be laid up at hand, as it were, in that same memory, where before they lay concealed, scattered and neglected, and so the more easily present themselves to the mind well accustomed to observe them.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 11:4
verses.text: And how many things of this sort does my memory retain which have been found out already, and, as I said, are, as it were, laid up ready to hand, which we are said to have learned and to have known; which, should we for small intervals of time cease to recall, they are again so submerged and slide back, as it were, into the more remote chambers, that they must be evolved thence again as if new (for other sphere they have none), and must be marshalled cogenda again that they may become known; that is to say, they must be collected colligenda, as it were, from their dispersion; whence we have the word cogitare.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 11:5
verses.text: For cogo I collect and cogito I recollect have the same relation to each other as ago and agito, facio and factito.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 11:6
verses.text: But the mind has appropriated to itself this word cogitation, so that not that which is collected anywhere, but what is collected, that is marshalled, in the mind, is properly said to be "cogitated".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 12:2
verses.text: —On the Recollection of Things Mathematical.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 12:3
verses.text: The memory containeth also the reasons and innumerable laws of numbers and dimensions, none of which hath any sense of the body impressed, seeing they have neither colour, nor sound, nor taste, nor smell, nor sense of touch.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 12:4
verses.text: I have heard the sound of the words by which these things are signified when they are discussed; but the sounds are one thing, the things another.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 12:5
verses.text: For the sounds are one thing in Greek, another in Latin; but the things themselves are neither Greek, nor Latin, nor any other language.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 12:6
verses.text: I have seen the lines of the craftsmen, even the finest, like a spider's web; but these are of another kind, they are not the images of those which the eye of my flesh showed me; he knoweth them who, without any idea whatsoever of a body, perceives them within himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 12:7
verses.text: I have also observed the numbers of the things with which we number all the senses of the body; but those by which we number are of another kind, nor are they the images of these, and therefore they certainly are.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 12:8
verses.text: Let him who sees not these things mock me for saying them; and I will pity him, whilst he mocks me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 13:2
verses.text: —Memory Retains All Things.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 13:3
verses.text: All these things I retain in my memory, and how I learnt them I retain.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 13:4
verses.text: I retain also many things which I have heard most falsely objected against them, which though they be false, yet is it not false that I have remembered them; and I remember, too, that I have distinguished between those truths and these falsehoods uttered against them; and I now see that it is one thing to distinguish these things, another to remember that I often distinguished them, when I often reflected upon them.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 13:5
verses.text: I both remember, then, that I have often understood these things, and what I now distinguish and comprehend I store away in my memory, that hereafter I may remember that I understood it now.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 13:6
verses.text: Therefore also I remember that I have remembered; so that if afterwards I shall call to mind that I have been able to remember these things, it will be through the power of memory that I shall call it to mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Manner in Which Joy and Sadness May Be Brought Back to the Mind and Memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:3
verses.text: This same memory contains also the affections of my mind; not in the manner in which the mind itself contains them when it suffers them, but very differently according to a power peculiar to memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:4
verses.text: For without being joyous, I remember myself to have had joy; and without being sad, I call to mind my past sadness; and that of which I was once afraid, I remember without fear; and without desire recall a former desire.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:5
verses.text: Again, on the contrary, I at times remember when joyous my past sadness, and when sad my joy.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:6
verses.text: Which is not to be wondered at as regards the body; for the mind is one thing, the body another.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:7
verses.text: If I, therefore, when happy, recall some past bodily pain, it is not so strange a thing.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:8
verses.text: But now, as this very memory itself is mind (for when we give orders to have a thing kept in memory, we say, "See that you bear this in mind;" and when we forget a thing, we say, "It did not enter my mind," and, "It slipped from my mind," thus calling the memory itself mind), as this is so, how comes it to pass that when being joyful I remember my past sorrow, the mind has joy, the memory sorrow,—the mind, from the joy than is in it, is joyful, yet the memory, from the sadness that is in it, is not sad? Does not the memory perchance belong unto the mind? Who will say so? The memory doubtless is, so to say, the belly of the mind, and joy and sadness like sweet and bitter food, which, when entrusted to the memory, are, as it were, passed into the belly, where they can be reposited, but cannot taste.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:9
verses.text: It is ridiculous to imagine these to be alike; and yet they are not utterly unlike.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:10
verses.text: But behold, out of my memory I educe it, when I affirm that there be four perturbations of the mind,—desire, joy, fear, sorrow; and whatsoever I shall be able to dispute on these, by dividing each into its peculiar species, and by defining it, there I find what I may say, and thence I educe it; yet am I not disturbed by any of these perturbations when by remembering them I call them to mind; and before I recollected and reviewed them, they were there; wherefore by remembrance could they be brought thence.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:11
verses.text: Perchance, then, even as meat is in ruminating brought up out of the belly, so by calling to mind are these educed from the memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 14:12
verses.text: Why, then, does not the disputant, thus recollecting, perceive in the mouth of his meditation the sweetness of joy or the bitterness of sorrow? Is the comparison unlike in this because not like in all points? For who would willingly discourse on these subjects, if, as often as we name sorrow or fear, we should be compelled to be sorrowful or fearful? And yet we could never speak of them, did we not find in our memory not merely the sounds of the names, according to the images imprinted on it by the senses of the body, but the notions of the things themselves, which we never received by any door of the flesh, but which the mind itself, recognising by the experience of its own passions, entrusted to the memory, or else which the memory itself retained without their being entrusted to it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:2
verses.text: —In Memory There are Also Images of Things Which are Absent.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:3
verses.text: But whether by images or no, who can well affirm? For I name a stone, I name the sun, and the things themselves are not present to my senses, but their images are near to my memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:4
verses.text: I name some pain of the body, yet it is not present when there is no pain; yet if its image were not in my memory, I should be ignorant what to say concerning it, nor in arguing be able to distinguish it from pleasure.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:5
verses.text: I name bodily health when sound in body; the thing itself is indeed present with me, but unless its image also were in my memory, I could by no means call to mind what the sound of this name signified.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:6
verses.text: Nor would sick people know, when health was named, what was said, unless the same image were retained by the power of memory, although the thing itself were absent from the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:7
verses.text: I name numbers whereby we enumerate; and not their images, but they themselves are in my memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:8
verses.text: I name the image of the sun, and this, too, is in my memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:9
verses.text: For I do not recall the image of that image, but itself, for the image itself is present when I remember it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:10
verses.text: I name memory, and I know what I name.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 15:11
verses.text: But where do I know it, except in the memory itself? Is it also present to itself by its image, and not by itself?.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:2
verses.text: —The Privation of Memory is Forgetfulness.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:3
verses.text: When I name forgetfulness, and know, too, what I name, whence should I know it if I did not remember it? I do not say the sound of the name, but the thing which it signifies which, had I forgotten, I could not know what that sound signified.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:4
verses.text: When, therefore, I remember memory, then is memory present with itself, through itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:5
verses.text: But when I remember forgetfulness, there are present both memory and forgetfulness,—memory, whereby I remember, forgetfulness, which I remember.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:6
verses.text: But what is forgetfulness but the privation of memory? How, then, is that present for me to remember, since, when it is so, I cannot remember? But if what we remember we retain in memory, yet, unless we remembered forgetfulness, we could never at the hearing of the name know the thing meant by it, then is forgetfulness retained by memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:7
verses.text: Present, therefore, it is, lest we should forget it; and being so, we do forget.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:8
verses.text: Is it to be inferred from this that forgetfulness, when we remember it, is not present to the memory through itself, but through its image; because, were forgetfulness present through itself, it would not lead us to remember, but to forget? Who will now investigate this? Who shall understand how it is?.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:9
verses.text: Truly, O Lord, I labour therein, and labour in myself.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:10
verses.text: I am become a troublesome soil that requires overmuch labour.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:11
verses.text: For we are not now searching out the tracts of heaven, or measuring the distances of the stars, or inquiring about the weight of the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:12
verses.text: It is I myself—I, the mind—who remember.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:13
verses.text: It is not much to be wondered at, if what I myself am not be far from me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:14
verses.text: But what is nearer to me than myself? And, behold, I am not able to comprehend the force of my own memory, though I cannot name myself without it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:15
verses.text: For what shall I say when it is plain to me that I remember forgetfulness? Shall I affirm that which I remember is not in my memory? Or shall I say that forgetfulness is in my memory with the view of my not forgetting? Both of these are most absurd.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:16
verses.text: What third view is there? How can I assert that the image of forgetfulness is retained by my memory, and not forgetfulness itself, when I remember it? And how can I assert this, seeing that when the image of anything is imprinted on the memory, the thing itself must of necessity be present first by which that image may be imprinted? For thus do I remember Carthage; thus, all the places to which I have been; thus, the faces of men whom I have seen, and things reported by the other senses; thus, the health or sickness of the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:17
verses.text: For when these objects were present, my memory received images from them, which, when they were present, I might gaze on and reconsider in my mind, as I remembered them when they were absent.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:18
verses.text: If, therefore, forgetfulness is retained in the memory through its image, and not through itself, then itself was once present, that its image might be taken.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 16:19
verses.text: But when it was present, how did it write its image on the memory, seeing that forgetfulness by its presence blots out even what it finds already noted? And yet, in whatever way, though it be incomprehensible and inexplicable, yet most certain I am that I remember also forgetfulness itself, whereby what we do remember is blotted out.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:2
verses.text: —God Cannot Be Attained Unto by the Power of Memory, Which Beasts and Birds Possess.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:3
verses.text: Great is the power of memory; very wonderful is it, O my God, a profound and infinite manifoldness; and this thing is the mind, and this I myself am.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:4
verses.text: What then am I, O my God? Of what nature am I? A life various and manifold, and exceeding vast.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:5
verses.text: Behold, in the numberless fields, and caves, and caverns of my memory, full without number of numberless kinds of things, either through images, as all bodies are; or by the presence of the things themselves, as are the arts; or by some notion or observation, as the affections of the mind are, which, even though the mind doth not suffer, the memory retains, while whatsoever is in the memory is also in the mind: through all these do I run to and fro, and fly; I penetrate on this side and that, as far as I am able, and nowhere is there an end.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:6
verses.text: So great is the power of memory, so great the power of life in man, whose life is mortal.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:7
verses.text: What then shall I do, O Thou my true life, my God? I will pass even beyond this power of mine which is called memory—I will pass beyond it, that I may proceed to Thee, O Thou sweet Light.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:8
verses.text: What sayest Thou to me? Behold, I am soaring by my mind towards Thee who remainest above me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:9
verses.text: I will also pass beyond this power of mine which is called memory, wishful to reach Thee whence Thou canst be reached, and to cleave unto Thee whence it is possible to cleave unto Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:10
verses.text: For even beasts and birds possess memory, else could they never find their lairs and nests again, nor many other things to which they are used; neither indeed could they become used to anything, but by their memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:11
verses.text: I will pass, then, beyond memory also, that I may reach Him who has separated me from the four-footed beasts and the fowls of the air, making me wiser than they.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:12
verses.text: I will pass beyond memory also, but where shall I find Thee, O Thou truly good and assured sweetness? But where shall I find Thee? If I find Thee without memory, then am I unmindful of Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 17:13
verses.text: And how now shall I find Thee, if I do not remember Thee?.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 18:2
verses.text: —A Thing When Lost Could Not Be Found Unless It Were Retained in the Memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 18:3
verses.text: For the woman who lost her drachma, and searched for it with a lamp, unless she had remembered it, would never have found it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 18:4
verses.text: For when it was found, whence could she know whether it were the same, had she not remembered it? I remember to have lost and found many things; and this I know thereby, that when I was searching for any of them, and was asked, "Is this it?" "Is that it?" I answered "No," until such time as that which I sought were offered to me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 18:5
verses.text: Which had I not remembered,—whatever it were,—though it were offered me, yet would I not find it, because I could not recognise it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 18:6
verses.text: And thus it is always, when we search for and find anything that is lost.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 18:7
verses.text: Notwithstanding, if anything be by accident lost from the sight, not from the memory,—as any visible body,—the image of it is retained within, and is searched for until it be restored to sight; and when it is found, it is recognised by the image which is within.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 18:8
verses.text: Nor do we say that we have found what we had lost unless we recognise it; nor can we recognise it unless we remember it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 18:9
verses.text: But this, though lost to the sight, was retained in the memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:2
verses.text: —What It is to Remember.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:3
verses.text: But how is it when the memory itself loses anything, as it happens when we forget anything and try to recall it? Where finally do we search, but in the memory itself? And there, if perchance one thing be offered for another, we refuse it, until we meet with what we seek; and when we do, we exclaim, "This is it!" which we should not do unless we knew it again, nor should we recognise it unless we remembered it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:4
verses.text: Assuredly, therefore, we had forgotten it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:5
verses.text: Or, had not the whole of it slipped our memory, but by the part by which we had hold was the other part sought for; since the memory perceived that it did not revolve together as much as it was accustomed to do, and halting, as if from the mutilation of its old habit, demanded the restoration of that which was wanting.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:6
verses.text: For example, if we see or think of some man known to us, and, having forgotten his name, endeavour to recover it, whatsoever other thing presents itself is not connected with it; because it was not used to be thought of in connection with him, and is consequently rejected, until that is present whereon the knowledge reposes fittingly as its accustomed object.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:7
verses.text: And whence, save from the memory itself, does that present itself? For even when we recognise it as put in mind of it by another, it is thence it comes.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:8
verses.text: For we do not believe it as something new, but, as we recall it, admit what was said to be correct.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:9
verses.text: But if it were entirely blotted out of the mind, we should not, even when put in mind of it, recollect it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:10
verses.text: For we have not as yet entirely forgotten what we remember that we have forgotten.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 19:11
verses.text: A lost notion, then, which we have entirely forgotten, we cannot even search for.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:2
verses.text: —We Should Not Seek for God and the Happy Life Unless We Had Known It.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:3
verses.text: How, then, do I seek Thee, O Lord? For when I seek Thee, my God, I seek a happy life.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:4
verses.text: I will seek Thee, that my soul may live.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:5
verses.text: For my body liveth by my soul, and my soul liveth by Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:6
verses.text: How, then, do I seek a happy life, seeing that it is not mine till I can say, "It is enough!" in that place where I ought to say it? How do I seek it? Is it by remembrance, as though I had forgotten it, knowing too that I had forgotten it? or, longing to learn it as a thing unknown, which either I had never known, or had so forgotten it as not even to remember that I had forgotten it? Is not a happy life the thing that all desire, and is there any one who altogether desires it not? But where did they acquire the knowledge of it, that they so desire it? Where have they seen it, that they so love it? Truly we have it, but how I know not.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:7
verses.text: Yea, there is another way in which, when any one hath it, he is happy; and some there be that are happy in hope.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:8
verses.text: These have it in an inferior kind to those that are happy in fact; and yet are they better off than they who are happy neither in fact nor in hope.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:9
verses.text: And even these, had they it not in some way, would not so much desire to be happy, which that they do desire is most certain.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:10
verses.text: How they come to know it, I cannot tell, but they have it by some kind of knowledge unknown to me, who am in much doubt as to whether it be in the memory; for if it be there, then have we been happy once; whether all individually, or as in that man who first sinned, in whom also we all died, and from whom we are all born with misery, I do not now ask; but I ask whether the happy life be in the memory? For did we not know it, we should not love it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:11
verses.text: We hear the name, and we all acknowledge that we desire the thing; for we are not delighted with the sound only.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:12
verses.text: For when a Greek hears it spoken in Latin, he does not feel delighted, for he knows not what is spoken; but we are delighted, as he too would be if he heard it in Greek; because the thing itself is neither Greek nor Latin, which Greeks and Latins, and men of all other tongues, long so earnestly to obtain.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:13
verses.text: It is then known unto all, and could they with one voice be asked whether they wished to be happy, without doubt they would all answer that they would.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 20:14
verses.text: And this could not be unless the thing itself, of which it is the name, were retained in their memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:2
verses.text: —How a Happy Life May Be Retained in the Memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:3
verses.text: But is it so as one who has seen Carthage remembers it? No.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:4
verses.text: For a happy life is not visible to the eye, because it is not a body.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:5
verses.text: Is it, then, as we remember numbers? No.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:6
verses.text: For he that hath these in his knowledge strives not to attain further; but a happy life we have in our knowledge, and, therefore, do we love it, while yet we wish further to attain it that we may be happy.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:7
verses.text: Is it, then, as we remember eloquence? No.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:8
verses.text: For although some, when they hear this name, call the thing to mind, who, indeed, are not yet eloquent, and many who wish to be so, whence it appears to be in their knowledge; yet have these by their bodily perceptions noticed that others are eloquent, and been delighted with it, and long to be so,—although they would not be delighted save for some interior knowledge, nor desire to be so unless they were delighted,—but a happy life we can by no bodily perception make experience of in others.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:9
verses.text: Is it, then, as we remember joy? It may be so; for my joy I remember, even when sad, like as I do a happy life when I am miserable.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:10
verses.text: Nor did I ever with perception of the body either see, hear, smell, taste, or touch my joy; but I experienced it in my mind when I rejoiced; and the knowledge of it clung to my memory, so that I can call it to mind sometimes with disdain and at others with desire, according to the difference of the things wherein I now remember that I rejoiced.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:11
verses.text: For even from unclean things have I been bathed with a certain joy, which now calling to mind, I detest and execrate; at other times, from good and honest things, which, with longing, I call to mind, though perchance they be not nigh at hand, and then with sadness do I call to mind a former joy.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:12
verses.text: Where and when, then, did I experience my happy life, that I should call it to mind, and love and long for it? Nor is it I alone or a few others who wish to be happy, but truly all; which, unless by certain knowledge we knew, we should not wish with so certain a will.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:13
verses.text: But how is this, that if two men be asked whether they would wish to serve as soldiers one, it may be, would reply that he would, the other that he would not; but if they were asked whether they would wish to be happy, both of them would unhesitatingly say that they would; and this one would wish to serve, and the other not, from no other motive but to be happy? Is it, perchance, that as one joys in this, and another in that, so do all men agree in their wish for happiness, as they would agree, were they asked, in wishing to have joy,—and this joy they call a happy life? Although, then, one pursues joy in this way, and another in that, all have one goal, which they strive to attain, namely, to have joy.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 21:14
verses.text: This life, being a thing which no one can say he has not experienced, it is on that account found in the memory, and recognised whenever the name of a happy life is heard.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 22:2
verses.text: —A Happy Life is to Rejoice in God, and for God.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 22:3
verses.text: Let it be far, O Lord,—let it be far from the heart of Thy servant who confesseth unto Thee; let it be far from me to think myself happy, be the joy what it may.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 22:4
verses.text: For there is a joy which is not granted to the "wicked," but to those who worship Thee thankfully, whose joy Thou Thyself art.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 22:5
verses.text: And the happy life is this,—to rejoice unto Thee, in Thee, and for Thee; this it is, and there is no other.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 22:6
verses.text: But those who think there is another follow after another joy, and that not the true one.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 22:7
verses.text: Their will, however, is not turned away from some shadow of joy.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:2
verses.text: —All Wish to Rejoice in the Truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:3
verses.text: It is not, then, certain that all men wish to be happy, since those who wish not to rejoice in Thee, which is the only happy life, do not verily desire the happy life.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:4
verses.text: Or do all desire this, but because "the flesh lusteth against the spirit, and the spirit against the flesh," so that they "cannot do the things that they would," they fall upon that which they are able to do, and with that are content; because that which they are not able to do, they do not so will as to make them able? For I ask of every man, whether he would rather rejoice in truth or in falsehood.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:5
verses.text: They will no more hesitate to say, "in truth," than to say, "that they wish to be happy".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:6
verses.text: For a happy life is joy in the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:7
verses.text: For this is joy in Thee, who art "the truth," O God, "my light," "the health of my countenance, and my God".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:8
verses.text: All wish for this happy life; this life do all wish for, which is the only happy one; joy in the truth do all wish for.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:9
verses.text: I have had experience of many who wished to deceive, but not one who wished to be deceived.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:10
verses.text: Where, then, did they know this happy life, save where they knew also the truth? For they love it, too, since they would not be deceived.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:11
verses.text: And when they love a happy life, which is naught else but joy in the truth, assuredly they love also the truth; which yet they would not love were there not some knowledge of it in the memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:12
verses.text: Wherefore, then, do they not rejoice in it? Why are they not happy? Because they are more entirely occupied with other things which rather make them miserable, than that which would make them happy, which they remember so little of.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:13
verses.text: For there is yet a little light in men; let them walk—let them "walk," that the "darkness" seize them not.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:14
verses.text: Why, then, doth truth beget hatred and that man of thine, preaching the truth become an enemy unto them, whereas a happy life is loved, which is naught else but joy in the truth; unless that truth is loved in such a sort as that those who love aught else wish that to be the truth which they love, and, as they are willing to be deceived, are unwilling to be convinced that they are so? Therefore do they hate the truth for the sake of that thing which they love instead of the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:15
verses.text: They love truth when she shines on them, and hate her when she rebukes them.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:16
verses.text: For, because they are not willing to be deceived, and wish to deceive, they love her when she reveals herself, and hate her when she reveals them.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:17
verses.text: On that account shall she so requite them, that those who were unwilling to be discovered by her she both discovers against their will, and discovers not herself unto them.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:18
verses.text: Thus, thus, truly thus doth the human mind, so blind and sick, so base and unseemly, desire to lie concealed, but wishes not that anything should be concealed from it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:19
verses.text: But the opposite is rendered unto it,—that itself is not concealed from the truth, but the truth is concealed from it.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:20
verses.text: Yet, even while thus wretched, it prefers to rejoice in truth rather than in falsehood.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 23:21
verses.text: Happy then will it be, when, no trouble intervening, it shall rejoice in that only truth by whom all things else are true.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 24:2
verses.text: —He Who Finds Truth, Finds God.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 24:3
verses.text: Behold how I have enlarged in my memory seeking Thee, O Lord; and out of it have I not found Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 24:4
verses.text: Nor have I found aught concerning Thee, but what I have retained in memory from the time I learned Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 24:5
verses.text: For from the time I learned Thee have I never forgotten Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 24:6
verses.text: For where I found truth, there found I my God, who is the Truth itself, which from the time I learned it have I not forgotten.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 24:7
verses.text: And thus since the time I learned Thee, Thou abidest in my memory; and there do I find Thee whensoever I call Thee to remembrance, and delight in Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 24:8
verses.text: These are my holy delights, which Thou hast bestowed upon me in Thy mercy, having respect unto my poverty.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 25:2
verses.text: —He is Glad that God Dwells in His Memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 25:3
verses.text: But where in my memory abidest Thou, O Lord, where dost Thou there abide? What manner of chamber hast Thou there formed for Thyself? What sort of sanctuary hast Thou erected for Thyself? Thou hast granted this honour to my memory, to take up Thy abode in it; but in what quarter of it Thou abidest, I am considering.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 25:4
verses.text: For in calling Thee to mind, I soared beyond those parts of it which the beasts also possess, since I found Thee not there amongst the images of corporeal things; and I arrived at those parts where I had committed the affections of my mind, nor there did I find Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 25:5
verses.text: And I entered into the very seat of my mind, which it has in my memory, since the mind remembers itself also—nor wert Thou there.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 25:6
verses.text: For as Thou art not a bodily image, nor the affection of a living creature, as when we rejoice, condole, desire, fear, remember, forget, or aught of the kind; so neither art Thou the mind itself, because Thou art the Lord God of the mind; and all these things are changed, but Thou remainest unchangeable over all, yet vouchsafest to dwell in my memory, from the time I learned Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 25:7
verses.text: But why do I now seek in what part of it Thou dwellest, as if truly there were places in it? Thou dost dwell in it assuredly, since I have remembered Thee from the time I learned Thee, and I find Thee in it when I call Thee to mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 26:2
verses.text: —God Everywhere Answers Those Who Take Counsel of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 26:3
verses.text: Where, then, did I find Thee, so as to be able to learn Thee? For Thou wert not in my memory before I learned Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 26:4
verses.text: Where, then, did I find Thee, so as to be able to learn Thee, but in Thee above me? Place there is none; we go both "backward" and "forward," and there is no place.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 26:5
verses.text: Everywhere, O Truth, dost Thou direct all who consult Thee, and dost at once answer all, though they consult Thee on divers things.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 26:6
verses.text: Clearly dost Thou answer, though all do not with clearness hear.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 26:7
verses.text: All consult Thee upon whatever they wish, though they hear not always that which they wish.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 26:8
verses.text: He is Thy best servant who does not so much look to hear that from Thee which he himself wisheth, as to wish that which he heareth from Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 27:2
verses.text: —He Grieves that He Was So Long Without God.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 27:3
verses.text: Too late did I love Thee, O Fairness, so ancient, and yet so new! Too late did I love Thee! For behold, Thou wert within, and I without, and there did I seek Thee; I, unlovely, rushed heedlessly among the things of beauty Thou madest.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 27:4
verses.text: Thou wert with me, but I was not with Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 27:5
verses.text: Those things kept me far from Thee, which, unless they were in Thee, were not.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 27:6
verses.text: Thou calledst, and criedst aloud, and forcedst open my deafness.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 27:7
verses.text: Thou didst gleam and shine, and chase away my blindness.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 27:8
verses.text: Thou didst exhale odours, and I drew in my breath and do pant after Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 27:9
verses.text: I tasted, and do hunger and thirst.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 27:10
verses.text: Thou didst touch me, and I burned for Thy peace.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:2
verses.text: —On the Misery of Human Life.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:3
verses.text: When I shall cleave unto Thee with all my being, then shall I in nothing have pain and labour; and my life shall be a real life, being wholly full of Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:4
verses.text: But now since he whom Thou fillest is the one Thou liftest up, I am a burden to myself, as not being full of Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:5
verses.text: Joys of sorrow contend with sorrows of joy; and on which side the victory may be I know not.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:6
verses.text: Woe is me! Lord, have pity on me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:7
verses.text: My evil sorrows contend with my good joys; and on which side the victory may be I know not.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:8
verses.text: Woe is me! Lord, have pity on me.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:9
verses.text: Woe is me! Lo, I hide not my wounds; Thou art the Physician, I the sick; Thou merciful, I miserable.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:10
verses.text: Is not the life of man upon earth a temptation? Who is he that wishes for vexations and difficulties? Thou commandest them to be endured, not to be loved.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:11
verses.text: For no man loves what he endures, though he may love to endure.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:12
verses.text: For notwithstanding he rejoices to endure, he would rather there were naught for him to endure.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:13
verses.text: In adversity, I desire prosperity; in prosperity, I fear adversity.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 28:14
verses.text: What middle place, then, is there between these, where human life is not a temptation? Woe unto the prosperity of this world, once and again, from fear of misfortune and a corruption of joy! Woe unto the adversities of this world, once and again, and for the third time, from the desire of prosperity; and because adversity itself is a hard thing, and makes shipwreck of endurance! Is not the life of man upon earth a temptation, and that without intermission?.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 29:2
verses.text: —All Hope is in the Mercy of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 29:3
verses.text: And my whole hope is only in Thy exceeding great mercy.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 29:4
verses.text: Give what Thou commandest, and command what Thou wilt.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 29:5
verses.text: Thou imposest continency upon us, "nevertheless, when I perceived," saith one, "that I could not otherwise obtain her, except God gave her me;.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 29:6
verses.text: that was a point of wisdom also to know whose gift she was".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 29:7
verses.text: For by continency are we bound up and brought into one, whence we were scattered abroad into many.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 29:8
verses.text: For he loves Thee too little who loves aught with Thee, which he loves not for Thee, O love, who ever burnest, and art never quenched! O charity, my God, kindle me! Thou commandest continency; give what Thou commandest, and command what Thou wilt.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:2
verses.text: —Of the Perverse Images of Dreams, Which He Wishes to Have Taken Away.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:3
verses.text: Verily, Thou commandest that I should be continent from the "lust of the flesh, and the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life".

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:4
verses.text: Thou hast commanded me to abstain from concubinage; and as to marriage itself, Thou hast advised something better than Thou hast allowed.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:5
verses.text: And because Thou didst give it, it was done; and that before I became a dispenser of Thy sacrament.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:6
verses.text: But there still exist in my memory—of which I have spoken much—the images of such things as my habits had fixed there; and these rush into my thoughts, though strengthless, when I am awake; but in sleep they do so not only so as to give pleasure, but even to obtain consent, and what very nearly resembles reality.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:7
verses.text: Yea, to such an extent prevails the illusion of the image, both in my soul and in my flesh, that the false persuade me, when sleeping, unto that which the true are not able when waking.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:8
verses.text: Am I not myself at that time, O Lord my God? And there is yet so much difference between myself and myself, in that instant wherein I pass back from waking to sleeping, or return from sleeping to waking! Where, then, is the reason which when waking resists such suggestions? And if the things themselves be forced on it, I remain unmoved.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:9
verses.text: Is it shut up with the eyes? Or is it put to sleep with the bodily senses? But whence, then, comes it to pass, that even in slumber we often resist, and, bearing our purpose in mind, and continuing most chastely in it, yield no assent to such allurements? And there is yet so much difference that, when it happeneth otherwise, upon awaking we return to peace of conscience; and by this same diversity do we discover that it was not we that did it, while we still feel sorry that in some way it was done in us.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:10
verses.text: Is not Thy hand able, O Almighty God, to heal all the diseases of my soul, and by Thy more abundant grace to quench even the lascivious motions of my sleep? Thou wilt increase in me, O Lord, Thy gifts more and more, that my soul may follow me to Thee, disengaged from the bird-lime of concupiscence; that it may not be in rebellion against itself, and even in dreams not simply not, through sensual images, commit those deformities of corruption, even to the pollution of the flesh, but that it may not even consent unto them.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:11
verses.text: For it is no great thing for the Almighty, who is "able to do.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:12
verses.text: above all that we ask or think," to bring it about that no such influence—not even so slight a one as a sign might restrain—should afford gratification to the chaste affection even of one sleeping; and that not only in this life, but at my present age.

verses.name: Augustine: Confessions Book X 30:13
